Arg1.RawText: The Kemper Corp. unit and other critics complain that program trading causes wild swings in stock prices, such as on Tuesday and on Oct. 13 and 16, and has increased chances for market crashes

Arg2.RawText: Over the past nine months, several firms, including discount broker Charles Schwab & Co. and Sears, Roebuck & Co. 's Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. unit, have attacked program trading as a major market evil

Arg1.RawText: But most of them, led by Morgan Stanley & Co., moved back in earlier this year

Arg2.RawText: The most volatile form of program trading is index arbitrage -- the rapid-fire, computer-guided buying and selling of stocks offset with opposite trades in stock-index futures and options

Arg1.RawText: The most volatile form of program trading is index arbitrage -- the rapid-fire, computer-guided buying and selling of stocks offset with opposite trades in stock-index futures and options

Arg2.RawText: The object is to capture profits from fleeting price discrepancies between the futures and options and the stocks themselves

Arg1.RawText: Index arbitrage recently has accounted for about half of all program trading on the New York Stock Exchange

Arg2.RawText: Last month, program trading accounted for 20.9 million shares a day, or a record 13.8% of the Big Board's average daily volume

Arg1.RawText: On Tuesday afternoon, Kemper told Bear, Stearns & Co., General Electric Co. 's Kidder, Peabody & Co. unit, Morgan Stanley and Oppenheimer & Co. that it will no longer do business with them because of their commitment to index arbitrage

Arg2.RawText: Kemper officials declined to identify the firms

Arg1.RawText: We've been opposed to" index arbitrage "for a long time

Arg2.RawText: Index arbitrage doesn't work, and it scares natural buyers" of stock

Arg1.RawText: that "on an intraday basis, it has major effects

Arg2.RawText: We've talked to proponents of index arbitrage and told them to cool it because they're ruining the market

Arg1.RawText: We've talked to proponents of index arbitrage and told them to cool it because they're ruining the market
Kemper also blasted the Big Board for ignoring the interests of individual and institutional holders

Arg2.RawText: The New York Stock Exchange has vested interests" in its big member securities firms "that cloud its objectivity," Mr. Timbers said. "It has never been interested in what we think.The Big Board also has a terrible communication problem with individual investors," he added

Arg1.RawText: The New York Stock Exchange has vested interests" in its big member securities firms "that cloud its objectivity

Arg2.RawText: It has never been interested in what we think

Arg1.RawText: Small investors perceive that "big operators" dominate the market

Arg2.RawText: they'd love to do away with it {program trading}, but they {the exchange} can't do it

Arg1.RawText: that he has no inclination to eliminate program trading

Arg2.RawText: but that all the exchange can do is "slow down the process" by using its circuit breakers and shock absorbers

Arg1.RawText: Morgan Stanley and Kidder Peabody, the two biggest program trading firms, staunchly defend their strategies

Arg2.RawText: We continue to believe the position we've taken is reasonable," a Morgan Stanley official said. "We would stop index arbitrage when the market is under stress, and we have recently," he said, citing Oct. 13 and earlier this week.Michael Carpenter, president and chief executive officer at Kidder Peabody, said in a recent interview, "We don't think that index arbitrage has a negative impact on the market as a whole

Arg1.RawText: the position we've taken is reasonable

Arg2.RawText: We would stop index arbitrage when the market is under stress

Arg1.RawText: We continue to believe the position we've taken is reasonable," a Morgan Stanley official said. "We would stop index arbitrage when the market is under stress, and we have recently," he said, citing Oct. 13 and earlier this week

Arg2.RawText: Michael Carpenter, president and chief executive officer at Kidder Peabody, said in a recent interview, "We don't think that index arbitrage has a negative impact on the market as a whole

Arg1.RawText: According to Lawrence Eckenfelder, a securities industry analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., "Kemper is the first firm to make a major statement with program trading

Arg2.RawText: that "having just one firm do this isn't going to mean a hill of beans
